docs.lead_paragraph: BILL CLINTON, while walking across your bridge to the 21st century, take a long look back at the middle part of this one. Divorce was rare and most children were born into two-parent families. Bob Dole, while harkening back to a country that you say was better and more civil, say hello to the early days of the 20th century, when Jim Crow was enforced formally in the South, informally elsewhere, and about 1 of 200 Americans was addicted to cocaine or opium.

headline.main: Campaigning on Portents of Doom and Boom

docs.abstract: Comment on Presidential campaign themes, which continue tradition in which challengers say country is floundering and incumbents say things are going well; Robert J Samuelson, author of book on the American dream, notes that Americans are so accustomed to quantum leaps in their quality of life that any leveling off is seen as decline (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: ON a humid morning last week, Michael D. Benjamin stood at the entrance to the subway station at Grand Army Plaza in Brooklyn, passing out campaign material and urging riders to vote for his candidate. Some people stopped and listened. Many simply darted by, looking more than a little annoyed. After all, Mr. Benjamin was stumping for a candidate in the Democratic primary for Brooklyn Surrogate. The race hardly evokes the passion of the Clinton-Dole campaign. But to Mr. Benjamin, a Brooklyn insurance broker and political lieutenant of Assemblyman Anthony J. Genovesi of Canarsie, the Surrogate race is a hot event. ''I'm out here in the heat,'' Mr. Benjamin said. ''But this race is important to me. And I'm out in the street trying to help people get involved politically, to care about what's going on.''
docs.abstract: Jonathan P Hicks article on ten upcoming primary races in New York City to watch; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Allison Mary Clinton and Adam Joseph Rak, legislative aides in Connecticut's Congressional delegation in Washington, were married yesterday in Squaw Valley, Calif. The Rev. Paul Soukup officiated at Queen of the Snows Roman Catholic Church. Mrs. Rak, 26, is the legislative director for Representative Christopher Shays, a Fairfield County Republican. She graduated from Santa Clara University and received a master's degree in public communications from American University. She is a daughter of Nina and John Clinton of San Carlos, Calif. Mr. Clinton retired as the president and publisher of The San Mateo (Calif.) Times, where his father, the late J. Hart Clinton, was the editor and publisher. The bride's mother is a resource specialist at the White Oaks Elementary School in San Carlos.

headline.main: Adam J. Rak, Allison M. Clinton

docs.lead_paragraph: In the vasectomy department of a birth control clinic serving this city's hard-pressed southern quarters, a single letter stamped with official seals lies pressed under the doctor's glass desktop. Without exception, the wary men shuffling into the office first seek reassurance that the operation will not result in their voices rising or their beards falling out. Then, in this ardent Muslim theocracy, the questions often swing around to whether Islam condones the procedure.

headline.main: With Iran Population Boom, Vasectomy Receives Blessing

docs.abstract: Iran's Islamic revolution, trying to curb population boom, has given religious approval to vasectomy as birth control method; faces staggering problems managing population that has risen to over 60 million from 35 million since 1979 as clerics exhorted Iranians to make babies; Iran, in rapid policy shift, now has one of world's most aggressive programs to encourage smaller families; graphs; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''The Squeeze on Medical Costs'' (editorial, Sept. 4) perpetuates wishful thinking about the effect of cost containment -- that ''cuts in payments to doctors'' translate into a reduction of ''needless tests, operations and other procedures.''

headline.main: Yes, Cut Medical Costs, but First Do No Harm

docs.abstract: Dr Robert L Soley letter says first principle in medical care is to do no harm

docs.lead_paragraph: With thousands of hospital aides, teachers and electrical workers as well as a re-election-minded Mayor stepping down Fifth Avenue, yesterday's union parade was in many ways like Labor Day parades of old, but with a new date and theme as part of labor's efforts to gain members and clout. The dozens of New York unions sponsoring the parade rescheduled it for the first Saturday after Labor Day to attract more marchers and spectators. With the parade's slogan ''America Needs a Raise,'' the unions adopted a theme designed to warm the public to labor and show that unions are out to help not just their members but all workers.

headline.main: Union Members March On a Rescheduled Day

docs.abstract: New York City unions hold Labor Day parade on Saturday after holiday; photos (S)
